head.title: The Northeast Can't Afford to Wait for Gas

hedline.hl1: The Northeast Can't Afford to Wait for Gas

block.p: In your July 7 editorial on the proposed Iroquois pipeline to bring Canadian gas to the Northeastern United States, you hit the nail squarely on the head when you say that the Northeast ''needs more natural gas and needs it soon.'' Among other benefits, this gas could increase our flexibility in the event of another oil supply shock and also would alleviate the Northeast's critical acid rain problem.
But as you also pointed out, pending applications for increasing current pipeline capacity will be approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission no earlier than 1992!

To help break this bureaucratic gridlock, we are establishing the Northeast Gas Congressional Caucus. The caucus neither favors one proposed project over another nor expresses a public policy preference for natural gas over other fuels. Rather, it hopes to insure that the commission obtains all pertinent information and, by working with all concerned agencies and parties, reaches an appropriate and expeditious resolution.

The Northeast cannot afford to wait another day, let alone four years, for this natural gas. Nevertheless, the Northeast would settle for a resolution as soon as possible. The purpose of the caucus is to achieve that end. (Rep.) NORMAN F. LENT (Rep.) J. JOSEPH MOAKLEY Washington, July 15, 1988 The writers are, respectively, chairman and vice chairman of the caucus.
